# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is a possible implementation of the function as described:
```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump=3)::DateTime
    if typeof(dt) != DateTime
        error("Only DateTime type supported.")
    end
    
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end
```

This function takes a `DateTime` instance and adds the specified amount of hours to it (defaulting to 3 hours if no argument is given for `bump`). It returns a new `DateTime` instance with the added time. If an instance of `Date` is passed in, it throws an error since you only want this function to work on `DateTime`.

Please note that the `bump` parameter can be any positive or negative integer value and not just 3 hours as specified in your initial request. You could also make it a keyword argument if you wanted to allow for more flexibility.
